prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Estimate of required sensitivity and angular resolution for XID262
Continuum: We combined the UV to near-IR photometry available from the CANDELS public catalog (Guo et al. 2013) with the Herschel catalogs and built the whole SEDs of XID262. By mean of an SED decomposition technique that accounts for the contribution of direct stellar emission as well as of dust-reprocessed emission from an AGN and stars themselves (Vignali et al. 2009; Pozzi et al. 2010; Georgantopoulos et al. 2013) we derived L_IR, SFR and stellar mass, which are in good agreement with those quoted in the literature. Based on the best fit FIR SED we estimated a continuum flux density of 8.0mJy at 700um (band 8) for XID262. We computed the exposure time necessary to detect the continuum with S/N~30 over an aggregated bandwidth of >7GHz, which results to be 3.6 min. We require the maximum achievable resolution available in band 8, ~0.15 arcsec, since the source angular size may be smaller than 0.6 arcsec (~2 kpc at z~3.7) and we want to study its continuum morphology, i.e. dust distribution. The required high S/N would allow us to effectively deconvolve for the beamsize and place even tighter constraints to the source extension if it is unresolved.
[CII]158um line: We used the L_CII vs L_(40-500um) correlation derived by Maiolino et al. (2009) for galaxies at z~4 to estimate the [CII] peak flux density (assuming a line width of 200 km/s, as estimated from similar objects). That correlation perfectly applies to a target of ours (XID403) for which the [CII] emission is already known. For XID262 we expect a line peak flux density of 56 mJy. With an exposure time on source of 3.6 min, as driven by our requirements on the continuum detection, the [CII] line is expected to be detected with S/N=27.7 over a 70km/s channel width. This will allow us to precisely measure the line intensity and profile and accurately estimate the atomic gas mas from the [CII] luminosity by using the relation by Hailey-Dunsheath et al. (2010). The S/N we will achieve for the [CII] line is similar to what has been achieved by Wang et al. (2013) for their Cycle 0 observations of [CII] in z~6 QSOs, whose S/N and resolution were sufficient to study the gas dynamics. Because of our higher resolution, we will even improve over Wang et al. (2013).
Our observations will be performed in FDM with a spectral resolution of 0.7 km/s per channel. To avoid exceeding the maximum allowed datarate we will average over four channels in those basebands where only continuum emission is expected.
Estimate of required sensitivity and angular resolution for XID403
The same computations have been performed to estimate the continuum flux of XID403. For this object we only ask for continuum observations, since its [CII] line has been already observed in Cycle 0 (PI De Breuck).We then exploit the same tuning used for XID262 and place XID403 in the same science goal. Its continuum emission is expected to be detected with S/N=30 over a >7 GHz aggregated bandwidth.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA continuum and [CII]158um-line observations of five X-ray selected, Herschel-detected QSOs at z>3 in the CDFS, featuring host star formation rates of hundreds of Msun/yr. In 4 out of 5 targets the nucleus is obscured by an X-ray column density NH>1e23 cm^-2. Through band 8 observations with 0.15" FWHM resolution, i.e. half-light radius ~0.5 kpc at the median target redshift, we will measure: 1) morphology and compactness of star formation - as traced by the continuum emission from heated dust; 2) mass and density of the atomic gas - as traced by the [CII]-line emission. With 2.5 hr of ALMA time (including overheads) we will directly assess whether: 1) star formation is taking place in a compact (~0.5-2 kpc) region, with size similar to that of compact quiescent galaxies (cQGs) at z<3. This, coupled to other physical quantities such as SFR, stellar mass, gas depletion time, would reveal whether our targets are the likely progenitors of cQGs; 2) the host gas density is so high that it can produce most of the nuclear absorption measured from the X-ray spectra. This might explain why the fraction of heavily obscured QSOs has been observed to increase with redshift.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
